Expectation1: Maintain a friendly and approachable demeanor
Situation1: The acquaintance passes another person in a quiet hallway.
Situation2: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Story: I walked down the quiet hallway, my footsteps echoing softly. Ahead, I spotted Mark, someone I knew from the building—a familiar face, but not quite a friend. As an acquaintance, I knew I should smile, maybe offer a quick hello, keep things light and friendly. That’s what people expect, right? But my mind was still tangled in the last call I’d made as a telemarketer. The customer had bombarded me with technical questions about our new service, questions my script barely covered. I could still feel the pressure in my chest, the expectation to sound confident, to handle every objection smoothly, even when I didn’t have all the answers. Now, as Mark approached, I felt my face tighten, unsure if I could muster the easy friendliness he’d expect. My mind raced with half-remembered product details and the fear of being caught off guard—by him, by the next call, by myself. I wanted to be approachable, but I also wanted to retreat, to prepare, to not be exposed as uncertain. As we drew closer, I felt the two roles pulling me in opposite directions, and I hesitated, caught between a smile and a sigh.
